_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Existing process in a new vessel.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SiVance, LLC 
Risk Management Program
Executive Summary

Introduction
SiVance, LLC., operates an organic chemical manufacturing facility (Standard Industrial
Classification No. 2869- Industrial Organic Chemicals, Not Elsewhere Classified) which produces specialty silicone technologies and intermediates required to modify basic silicone polymers. The facility is located in Alachua County at 5002 N.E. 54th Place Gainesville, Florida. 

Accidental Release Prevention
Accidents and releases of all chemicals on site are prevented using a combination of employee training, procedure adherence, passive and active secondary containment, interlocks, alarms, and continuous process monitoring.

Emergency Response Policies 
SiVance, LLC maintains an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to define the roles and responsibilities of on-site personnel, the Emergency Response Team, the Medical Emergency Response Team, and the Fire Brigade.  The ERP uses the Incident Command System to define command, operations, planning, logistics, and finance during emergency response.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
SiVance, LLC includes seven process areas, a wastewater treatment system, bulk tank storage, warehouses, a quality control laboratory, and a research and development laboratory.  Chemical batching is performed in seven (7) process areas: Bldg. 51, Bldg. 48, Bldg. 43, Bldg. 39, Bldg. 25/26, Bldg. 18, and Bldg. 5.  Out of the regulated substances on-site, three are toxic chemicals (anhydrous ammonia, phosphorus oxychloride and trimethylchlorosilane) and five are flammable chemicals (acetylene, dichlorosilane, pentane, trichlorosilane, and tetramethylsilane).  In 2024, tetramethylsilane was used for the worst-case scenario due to an increase in quantity stored on site as of late December 2024.  Prior worst-case scenarios were performed using Acetylene.

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
SiVance follows OSHAs Process Safety Manageme

nt (PSM) standard 29 CFR 1910.119 which includes process safety information, process hazard analysis, process documentation, training, contractor control, pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity, hot work permits, management of change, incident investigation, emergency planning and response, compliance audits, and an associate participation program.   

The Five-Year Accident History
No major incidents released any chemical beyond the property boundary in the last five years.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
In addition to the PSM program referenced above, SiVance reports and documents safety concerns using a site hazard and incident reporting system. All hazards and incidents reported are reviewed by the Sites Management Team.  All safety concerns are prioritized for correction according to risk.  An incident investigation is completed following each incident to identify contributing factors and track corrective actions through completion.  Additionally, the site Safety Facilitator maintains a log of project ideas contributed by employees to improve safety and reviews the status of projects frequently with site employees.
